overview: The Andaman and Nicobar Islands are a remote archipelago of about 600 islands in the Bay of Bengal, politically part of India. They are known for pristine beaches, excellent scuba‑diving (especially around Havelock and Neil Islands), tropical forests and a mix of cultures. Most tourists stay on the Andaman side; only a few islands are open to visitors.
bestTimeToVisit: Mid‑January to mid‑May (dry, sunny, good diving conditions)
approximateDailyBudgetINR: ₹2,000–₹3,000 per day (budget accommodation, meals and local transport)
topAttractions: Mahatma Gandhi Marine National Park (coral reefs)
North Andaman, Middle Andaman and South Andaman (nature trails)
Radhanagar Beach (often rated among world’s best)
travelTips: Indian nationals need no permit for the Andamans; a Restricted Area Permit is required only for Nicobar islands and tribal reserves.
Cheapest entry is by government ferry from Chennai, Kolkata or Visakhapatnam (≈₹1,961, basic facilities).
Flights land at Veer Savarkar International Airport in Port Blair; no night flights after 3 PM.
Languages spoken include Hindi, Tamil, Bengali, Telugu and English; basic communication is easy.
Carry cash in INR as ATMs are limited on smaller islands.
Plan activities around the dry season (Jan‑May) to avoid monsoon rains and poor visibility for diving.
Book accommodation and dive operators in advance, especially during peak season.
